reporting-org.narrative: DCAF - Geneva Centre for Security Sector Governance

title.narrative: DCAF's International Security Sector Advisory Team (ISSAT)

description.narrative:
ISSAT is a multi-donor funded initiative that brings together 16 bilateral donors and a range of multilateral and regional actors active in supporting SSR processes (known as Governing Board Members), including the the African Union (AU), the European Union (EU), the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), the Organisation International de la Francophonie (OiF), the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE), the United Nations (UN), and the World Bank (WB) .
ISSAT provides one of the only forums where bilateral donors, multilateral and regional organisations can meet to discuss and coordinate operational activities related to SSR. Over 10 years of working closely with its Members, ISSAT has become a trusted, strategic partner for our GBMs that enables them to provide more politically engaged, evidence-based, context-specific, people-centred and effective S&J support, which contributes to improved development, stabilisation and conflict prevention

ISSAT’s goal is to reinforce and improve the way in which our GBMs individually and collectively support S&J development. Given the diversity of our GBMs’ needs, we achieve our operational goal through tailored individual assistance, as well as facilitating better coordinated approaches between and within GBMs through maximising our convening power and partnerships across our GBMs. This is provided across a range of advisory, professional development and training, and knowledge and outreach services

The International Security Sector Advisory Team (ISSAT) was officially created within DCAF – the Centre for Security Sector Governance on 8 February 2008. It is one of DCAF’s four departments and forms part of the multi-dimensional approach that DCAF has supporting Security Sector Governance.
ISSAT was set up in recognition of the need to increase the capacity of the international community to support Security Sector Governance/Reform (SSG/R) processes, to enhance the effectiveness and quality of SSG/R activities, and to facilitate the coordination and coherence of the international community’s support for nationally driven SSR procedures.

We have six objectives, which support improving our GBMs’ collective support to Security and Justice (S&J), reinforcing our GBMs individually in their S&J interventions, and reinforcing our GBMs’ institutional capacity to support S&J. These are to:
1. Enable better decision-making around S&J programming: a. Better prepare GBM decision-making through scoping-studies, assessments and mappings b. Better enable GBM adjustments in decision-making through monitoring and evaluation and lessons identification c. Better incorporate risk assessment and mitigation in GBM decision-making
2. Improve GBM coordination: a. Improve GBM approaches to cross-institutional or organisational support for S&J b. Improve the extent to which GBMs cooperate on ISSAT mandates
3. Enhance GBMs’ strategic approaches: a. Strengthen the development of GBMs’ strategic approaches for supporting S&J b. Enable the implementation of GBMs’ strategic approaches for supporting S&J
4. Build the business case for supporting S&J a. Develop a set of key S&J indicators to be integrated and monitored in S&J support b. Produce clear narratives for GBMs to articulate the added value of supporting S&J
5. Enhance GBMs’ capacities to deploy strategic S&J advisors a. Deliver high-quality training for GBMs b. Strengthen GBM systems to deploy strategic advisors
6. Provide a toolbox of approaches and examples of how to support S&J: a. Enable GBMs to integrate elements dealing with the prevention of violent conflict into their S&J programming b. Strengthen GBM’s access to examples on what has worked

title.narrative: DCAF/ISSAT's website is a resource for security and justice practitioners to Learn and Share good practice, post questions and comments, and link up with other practitioners
Progress Report for ISSAT’s 2016 Gender and SSR Related Work
ISSAT's 2017 Annual Report highlights our achievements over the past year, as well as the evolving trends in SSR and therefore the top issues for us to focus on in 2018
